awd_titl_txt: CDI Type II: New cyber-enabled strategies to realize the promise of quantum chemistry as a far-reaching tool for engineering applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to predict quantitatively how natural and engineered systems will behave is a critical element to the growth and advancement of technology. Such predictions are developed through the application of computers to mathematical models of the system of interest. All such systems are made of materials that are ultimately composed of countless molecules, but often it is not necessary to acknowledge this fact to make useful quantitative predictions. However, with the continued growth and sophistication of nanotechnology, the development of advanced materials, and the growing interest in extremes of application, recognition of the underlying role of molecules in producing physical behavior is indispensable for reliable and accurate predictions. The principles required to achieve this are well established in the laws of quantum mechanics, but the means to convert this understanding into predictions about macroscopic material behaviors is quite limited. Recent advances and trends in computer science and engineering present opportunities to remedy this situation. Two key developments are the advent of multicore processors and distributed computing in general and, apart from this, a focus on data-driven knowledge. Computationally-intensive methods must be reconsidered from the ground up to make real use of these advances in computer science. The promise of new computing technologies is not likely to be met without a more fundamental and radical reformulation of the basic computational approach. This project aims to contribute to these transformations. Future developments open up new avenues for experimental validation of first-principles computational chemistry methods (i.e., requiring no input from experiment), improving them and thereby technologies where they can be applied.

By supplying a route to fluid properties from first principles, this research provides an enabling technology across much of science and engineering while translating fundamental chemistry into applications via new cyber-approaches. Advances made in this project are expected to impact most directly chemical engineering, computational chemistry, and computer science, with a potentially broad array of secondary impacts in areas such as nanotechnology, materials science and engineering, geology, energy, atmospheric science and any other of the myriad fields that can benefit from the capability to predict and model material properties. The development of data-analysis schemes as part of this project can be extended and applied in unforeseen ways to other systems of discrete objects, and the computer-programming tools developed here aim to be sufficiently general to allow application to a diverse set of problems well beyond those that motivate this work. Additionally, education and outreach are promoted via a workshop for high-school students, and via distribution of new easy-to-use open-source software enabling others to apply the methods developed here in their own applications.

This is a Cyber-Enabled Discovery and Innovation Program award and is co-funded by the Division of Chemistry, the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities, the Directorate of Computer & Information Science and the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems.

por.por_cntn:
The broad aim of this work is the formulation of methods to apply first-principles ("ab initio") quantum chemistry to calculation of the properties of bulk phases. This work is timely because of recent advances in both computing capabilities and theoretical methods, which together are just now bringing the goals of this project within reach. The goals are important because physical-property prediction is the crucial “weak link” that hampers the development of many new technologies needed to tackle some of society’s most vexing problems. The general aim of work of this type is to allow property prediction to be performed with minimal experimental input, and in the best case solely from calculations using the basic equations of physics and chemistry. Such capability can then enable high-throughput computer-based exploration of substances and mixtures that can be used to meet a specific need. This very difficult problem is most tractable for systems in the solid and the gaseous phases, and the goals of this project are to advance our capabilities for the latter case, i.e., for gases and their mixtures.

The approach focuses on the use of first-principles methods in the calculation of so-called cluster integrals appearing in expressions for the thermodynamic properties. This general goal is advanced using a multi-pronged strategy:

  1. Integration of ab initio electronic-structure methods with cluster integral calculations. Two general approaches are examined. In the first, ab initio calculations are performed on-the-fly, providing an energy for each configuration of atoms as it is encountered in the cluster-integral calculation.  The project did not succeed in developing a satisfactory means to do this, but it has generated ideas for further development. The second general approach is to use models fit to first-principles data beforehand, and this has been very successful. Following it, we have produced calculations of properties that match or exceed the quality of experimental data for several different systems.
  2. Development and application of methods for nuclear quantum contributions. A technical issue arises in that quantum-mechanical effects on the nuclei are generally ignored in first-principles calculations, because attention is focused on the quantum features of the electrons. Still, these nuclear quantum effects are important for practical calculations, and methods are needed to compute them. Such considerations are not needed when using empirical potentials, because these effects are included when they are fit to experiment. We explored, developed, and applied methods for treating these effects, and produced results that can help understand when the various approaches are needed and when they will be effective.
  3. Formulation and porting of techniques to advanced hardware platforms. Cluster-integral methods are very well suited for implementation on distributed hardware platforms, and particularly on multi-processor graphics processing units (GPUs). Accordingly, one aim of the project has been to port the algorithms to these platforms, examine their performance, and adjust to make best use of these new capabilities. We succeeded in this goal, achieving speedups for the calculations of 10 to 100 times.
  4. Development of more efficient methods and data-enabled techniques for cluster-integral calculations. Cluster-integral methods have only recently been a topic of focused study, and so there continues to be advances in basic algorithms. Often these result as a byproduct of application to new classes of systems and phenomena. The project aims can benefit greatly from any advance in the basic methodology, so we have focused some effort in this direction. We have been successful in this goal as well, introducing new effective techniques for a variety of problems and system types.
  5. Probing and expanding scope of application of cluster methods. Assessing and extending the range of application of cluster methods can make knowledge of the cluster integrals much more valuable. Developments in this area encompass extending the framework to new classes of systems and phenomena, and developing methods to extend their range of applicability. In this category of activity we also conduct application of cluster methods with various types of molecular models, to determine how effective they are in describing bulk behavior. We made major advances in this direction, showing how novel and effective formulas can be constructed by taking known behavior at the vapor-liquid critical point and merging it with the description computed from the cluster integrals. The resulting form has shown effectiveness in some cases to densities twice as high as previously possible. We have also produced a comprehensive assessment of the cluster-based methods in computing a full set of thermodynamic properties, validating the behavior by comparison to values computed by other means. The outcome has shown the cluster methods to be robust and efficient while providing a reliable self-assessment of their performance, a capability wholly unique to these methods.
